FINAL SERMON
Paul Laz are fold has said "in the 20th Century there no longer is any still small
voice without the RESONANCE of mass communications"*
Technically in the 20th Century mankind is better able to communicate more infor¬
mation more rapidly than any time in the known history of the world.
The proposition that much of the communicated information is contradictory, worth¬
less, cheapening, confusing, and sometimes deliberately distorted requires little
argument.
Obviously devoted, sincere, and intelligent men in all walks of life (and especially
educators) have a duty and responsibility to improve and enrich our system of mass
communications.
In a republic dedicated to the principle of ballot and the rule of the majority—
a part of that Western World of free peoples, engaged (as Barbara Ward has said)
in a 500 year old experiment testing whether or not democracy will work—the role
of the mass media is supremely important.
Increasingly the "pictures of the world inside our heads" are derived from the
television screens.
If those pictures are distorted, or significant portions of the pictures are ab¬
sent, or if the pictures of the worthwhile and significant are not presented
often enough for people to understand and remember, then their concept of the
world is completely inadequate to provide any basis for self-government. Indeed
another step is for those who control the pictures by default or intent to do
the governing themselves.
Educators and educated men tend to shrink from the prospect the acceptance of
this responsibility poses—not only because of the fights, the problems, and the
difficulties the assumption of such a role suggests, but to a large degree be¬
cause they do not understand their indicated responsibility and whan they face,
in fact, the techniques of dealing with a so-called "mass" it appears at such
variance with their own well-ordered and cultivated universe of taste, reason,
and culture that they blanch at the descent into the market place.
A? I have said before, this is not precisely a matter of free choice*. Either
tie educator lives in this world or by absenting himself from it, allows the
conditions to be created that will end by destroying not only his special
miverse but the society that has permitted him this enjoyment.
Ie does not understand or appreciate how strongly the winds of anti-intel-
:.ectualisra are blowing; nor that the protection he has thus far enjoyed
is for other reasons than his own efforts. It is like the United States and
the Monroe Doctrine with American patriots fancying their promulgation was
effective because they said it, and not because of the British fleet. Can
any discerning educator doubt what a McCarthyism come to full flower should
mean? Can he doubt what sins of omission or emphasis on any major political
or social development would mean? Can he argue that he cannot afford to counter
this and should have been countering it via the mass media?
